intro: Helleborus heyderi, commonly known as the Turkish hellebore, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern Mediterranean region. It belongs to the family Ranunculaceae and is characterized by its dark green, leathery leaves and clusters of nodding, bell-shaped flowers that range in color from white to deep purple. The plant typically grows in woodland and rocky habitats, preferring partial shade and well-drained soil. Its flowering period occurs in late winter to early spring, making it one of the earliest blooming plants in its native range. Helleborus heyderi is also known for its toxic properties, containing various alkaloids that can be harmful if ingested.
